question: Will 50% or more of respondents to to Gallup's 2025 survey express sympathies for the the Israelis?
description: Survey is due to be released in March 2025.

**Munich Security Report 2025: International Perception of Turkey Becomes More Positive**
According to the Munich Security Report 2025, the international perception of Turkey is becoming increasingly positive as its global influence grows. In contrast, Israel is viewed as a 'threat' by an increasing number of countries. The report, titled 'Polar Multiplicity', was released on Monday, ahead of the 61st Munich Security Conference to be held on Friday. The survey, which covered various countries including Germany, the US, the UK, France, Italy, Brazil, Japan, Canada, India, China, and South Africa, showed that the views on Turkey, South Korea, Poland, and the UK have become more positive. In all countries surveyed except France, the percentage of people who view Turkey as an 'ally' is higher than those who view it as a 'threat'. The gap between those who view Turkey as an 'ally' and those who view it as a 'threat' is 28 points in the UK and Japan, 26 points in China, 25 points in India, 19 points in South Africa, 14 points in the US and Canada, 10 points in Brazil, 5 points in Italy, and 2 points in Germany. Turkey has become the second country, after South Korea, to record the highest number of positive opinions in this area, along with the UK, Brazil, and Poland. In contrast, the US and Israel are among the countries that have suffered the most in terms of their 'allies' image, with the percentage of people who view Israel as a 'threat' increasing rapidly compared to the previous survey. Israel is the only country viewed as a 'threat' by an increasing number of countries in the survey.

**Trump gets high approval ratings for his first weeks, new CBS poll finds**
A new CBS News/YouGov poll found that 53% of U.S. adults approve of Trump's overall job in office so far, with most respondents describing him as 'effective,' 'focused,' 'tough,' 'competent,' and 'energetic.' However, only 37% view him as 'compassionate.' The poll also found that 70% of respondents believe Trump is doing what he promised during the 2024 campaign. Despite this, Trump scored less-than-stellar marks on issues such as trade and inflation, with 51% of respondents believing his policies will make food and grocery prices go up. The poll also found that 73% of respondents think new U.S. tariffs on imported goods will make things more expensive for them. However, Trump's initial efforts to deport undocumented immigrants en masse garnered 59% approval, and his plan to send U.S. troops to the southern border to stop illegal crossings received 64% support. Trump's handling of the conflict between Israel and Hamas also drew the approval of 54% of respondents.

**CBS Survey: 53% of Americans Satisfied with Trump's Governance**
A recent CBS and YouGov joint survey found that 53% of respondents are satisfied with President Trump's overall governance, while 47% are dissatisfied. 70% of respondents believe that Trump is fulfilling his campaign promises, while 30% say he is not. The survey also found that most respondents think Trump's government has not done enough to reduce prices. CBS analyzed that inflation was a key factor in Trump's 2024 election victory. The survey also found that the most commonly used words to describe Trump are 'tough', 'energetic', 'focused', and 'effective', with support rates of 69%, 63%, 60%, and 58% respectively. The survey results also show that most Republican Party members and Trump supporters believe that Trump has done a good job in deporting illegal immigrants and stopping 'diversity, equity and inclusion' plans. The decision to send troops to the US-Mexico border also received widespread approval. However, the decision to build large detention centers for undocumented immigrants was met with opposition from 52% of respondents, while 48% supported it. Trump's handling of the conflict between Israel and Hamas received 54% approval, while 46% disapproved. When asked about Trump's idea to take over the Gaza Strip, 13% of respondents thought it was a good idea, while 47% thought it was a bad idea, and 40% were unsure. When asked about Trump's performance in reducing prices, 66% of respondents said he had not done enough, while 31% said he had done a good job, and 3% said he had done too much.

**Survey Finds 77.5% of Respondents Experienced Dissatisfaction at Work During 2025 New Year**
A survey conducted by 'Job総研' found that 77.5% of respondents felt that they had experienced dissatisfaction at work during the 2025 new year. Other sources of dissatisfaction included '同僚' (coworkers) and '休暇' (vacation). **Support for Hamas Rule in Gaza Increases Among Israeli Arabs**
A recent survey conducted by the Center for the Study of Public Opinion and Family Policy at the Israel Democracy Institute found that support for Hamas rule in Gaza has increased among Israeli Arabs by 20%. According to the survey, 29% of Israeli Arab respondents now support Hamas control, up from 8% in September 2024. In contrast, most Jewish respondents prefer multinational forces over Israeli control. The survey also found that optimism about national security has decreased, with only 41% of respondents feeling secure in January 2025, down from 51% in December 2024. This decrease in optimism is particularly notable among Jewish respondents, who saw a significant drop from 56% in December to 42% in January. Among Arab respondents, optimism actually increased from 23% to 35%. The survey was conducted from January 28 to February 2, 2025, and involved 755 Israeli citizens aged 18 and above, including 604 Jewish and 151 Arab respondents. 'It is a worrying trend that support for Hamas is increasing among Israeli Arabs,' said a spokesperson for the survey. 'We need to understand the reasons behind this trend and work to address them.'

**29% of Israeli Arabs Support Hamas Rule in Gaza, Survey Finds**
According to a survey conducted by the Viterbi Family Center for Public Opinion and Policy Research at the Israel Democracy Institute, support for Hamas control over Gaza among Israeli Arabs has increased by 20% since September 2024, reaching 29% in January 2025. When asked who should govern Gaza after the war, most Jewish respondents preferred multinational forces over Israeli control. Among Israeli Arab respondents, support for Hamas control surged from 8% in September 2024 to 29% in January 2025, making it their top choice. The survey, conducted from January 28 to February 2, 2025, involved 755 Israeli citizens aged 18 and above, including 604 Jewish and 151 Arab respondents. The results showed a decline in public optimism regarding national security, dropping to 41% in January 2025 from 51% in December 2024, returning to the level seen in November 2024. Jewish respondents' optimism decreased significantly, from 56% in December to 42% in January, while Arab respondents' optimism increased from 23% to 35%.

**Canadians worried about relations between Muslim and Jewish communities, survey says**
A recent survey conducted by the Canadian Research Insights Council found that Canadians are concerned about the relationship between Muslim and Jewish communities. The survey revealed that 34% of people aged 18-34 think the relationship is bad, while 49% of those 55 and older share the same opinion. Respondents in Quebec had the worst impression, while Albertans had the most optimistic perception. Experts, including Jack Jedwab, Amira Elghawaby, Michael Bueckert, Richard Robertson, and Deborah Lyons, weighed in on the issue, emphasizing the need for Canadians to come together and combat harmful narratives. They noted that the relationship between the two communities is often driven by events, such as the Hamas attack on Israel in October 2023, and that there is a need to improve the relationship. 'I think it’s largely driven by events post-October 7,' Jedwab said. 'The issue arising from that is, you know, is there something that needs to be done to try to improve that relationship?' Elghawaby added, 'It’s notable that the poll shows that people under the age of 35 are less inclined to feel that relations between Canadian Muslims and Canadian Jews are ‘bad.’ This is a hopeful sign for the future.'

**Israel's Moral Decay: A Nation of Sociopaths**
A survey by the Jewish People Policy Institute found that 'more than eight out of ten Israeli Jews support' the plan proposed by President Donald Trump to ethnically cleanse the Gaza Strip of Palestinians by resettling them in Egypt and Jordan. The survey also found that among the minority of Israelis who did not support the plan, only 13% opposed it because they considered it immoral. Among Israeli Jews specifically, the number who oppose the ethnic cleansing of Gaza for moral reasons is just 3%. As the author notes, 'if that's not a sign of a morally sick society, I don't know what is.' The author argues that this lack of empathy is a natural consequence of the systematic indoctrination of Israelis to view Palestinians as less than human, which is necessary for the existence of the State of Israel. The author also cites a 2011 survey that found that 61% of Israeli men do not consider rape to be a violation if it is committed by a known person, and that only 7% believe that marital rape is real. The author concludes that Israel is a nation of sociopaths, and that this is necessary for its existence as a state, which relies on violence, tyranny, and injustice.

**Most Israelis want completion of hostage deal with Hamas**
A recent survey by the Jewish People Policy Institute (JPPI) found that a majority of Israelis, including both Jews and Arabs, support completing the hostage deal with Hamas before deciding on the future of Hamas rule in Gaza. Among Arab respondents, three out of four support completing the deal, while among Jewish respondents, about one-quarter prefer halting the deal after the first phase and resuming military operations. The survey highlights significant ideological and political differences, with right-wing respondents being more divided, but overall, there is a clear majority in favor of completing the deal. According to the survey, supporters of Religious Zionism and Otzma Yehudit stand out in their preference for resuming the war, with 70% and 60% of voters favoring a return to military action, respectively. However, religious Israelis overall are more divided, with 45% supporting completing the deal and 38% favoring halting the deal and returning to war.

**Arab Israelis Identify with Israel, Reject Hamas' Narrative**
A recent survey conducted in Israel shows that the majority of Arab citizens (68%) believe that the Hamas attack on October 7, 2023, which killed 1,200 Israelis and injured thousands, does not reflect the values of Arab society, the Palestinian people, and the Islamic nation. The survey also found that 86% of Arab citizens are in favor of helping civil volunteer efforts in the war between Israel and Hamas, while 70% declare themselves part of Israel and its problems. Professor Mouna Maroun, vice-president and dean of research at the University of Haifa, stated: 'I am an Arab Israeli (...) I am embarrassed. And the blame is on Hamas, (...) For the sake of humanity, I implore the Arab community to move forward and intelligently and responsibly understand the Jewish narrative, as we have asked them to understand our narrative for 75 years. For the first time, as a minority Arab, we are asked to be empathetic and understand the narrative of the majority... ' Maroun added: 'In the city of Haifa, there are neighborhoods and residential buildings inhabited by Arab Israelis and Jews. At the university, Jews and Arabs learn and grow together. This is the paradigm that Israel must replicate to overcome the tragedy of October 7.' The survey also found that the percentage of Arab citizens in Israel who identify with Israel is increasing, with 66% in favor of a Arab party joining the Israeli government coalition. Fahima Abbas, a researcher at the Adva Center, stated: 'Hospitals, where many people experience pain and illness, are also places of cooperation between Jewish and Arab doctors. It is our duty to remember and strengthen this cooperation in both normal and emergency situations.' The article concludes that Arab Israeli leaders who continue to act against the interests of their own people are causing harm to their constituents, making them appear as a 'fifth column', an internal enemy. The article also mentions that at least 23 Arab Israeli citizens were killed by Hamas terrorists during the October 7 attack or by missile attacks launched by the organization in the following days. Many Bedouin men and women were also kidnapped by Hamas. The article ends with a call for Arab Israeli citizens to liberate themselves from extremist leaders who speak and act against the interests of the Arab community in Israel.

**70% of Israelis Support Completing Prisoner Exchange Deal with Gaza**
A recent poll in Israel found that 70% of Israelis support completing the prisoner exchange deal with Palestinian factions in the Gaza Strip, while 17% believe that Israel should return to its policy of 'extermination' in Gaza after the first phase of the deal is completed. According to the poll conducted by the Israeli newspaper 'Israel Hayom', 4% of respondents oppose the deal in all its phases, and 9% refused to express their opinions. The poll also found that 58% of respondents within the ruling Likud party, led by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, support completing the deal in all its phases. In contrast, 95% of respondents from opposition parties support completing the deal in all its phases. The poll was conducted in the context of a ceasefire between Hamas and Israel, which began on January 1, 2024, and is currently in its first phase, lasting 42 days, during which negotiations are taking place to begin the second and third phases, mediated by Egypt, Qatar, and the United States. The poll also highlighted that in the event of elections being held today, the Likud party would win 23 seats in the Knesset, compared to 28 seats for former Prime Minister Naftali Bennett, who is expected to return to the political scene in the upcoming Israeli elections.

**Trend reversal: Poll shows most Israelis oppose Palestinian state – Cleveland Jewish News**
For the first time in nearly 18 years, a majority of Israeli Jews oppose the establishment of a Palestinian state, according to a recent opinion poll. The 'Swords of Iron Survey Results—December 2024' survey by Tel Aviv University's Institute for National Security Studies found that 64% of Jewish respondents opposed the creation of a Palestinian state 'under any condition', while 23% supported it 'under certain conditions'. Among Arab respondents, 59% opposed the creation of a Palestinian state. The survey also found that 85% of Jewish respondents had 'great confidence' in the Israel Defense Forces, compared to 34% among Arabs. Confidence in the government remained stable, with 25% among Jewish respondents and 9% among Arabs. The survey had a reported 3.5% error margin.

**Israelis Still Struggling with War-Related Trauma, Survey Finds**
A recent survey conducted by the Ruppin Academic Center in Israel has shown that the country's population is still struggling with the effects of the war that began on October 7, 2023. The survey found that 50% of respondents reported a significant decline in their quality of life, 60% reported a decline in their self-confidence, and 26.7% reported suicidal thoughts. The survey also found that women, soldiers, Arabs, and evacuees are at a higher risk of experiencing psychological trauma. Professor Yossi Levi-Belz, the head of the Center for the Study of Suicidality and Psychiatric Disorders at the Ruppin Academic Center, said, 'The organism and psyche are struggling to cope with what they have experienced, which is expressed in impatience, difficulties with concentration, strong stress, and an inability to truly enjoy something. Citizens feel like their life has stopped.' The survey also found that 55.1% of respondents reported physical symptoms such as pain in the stomach or back, 51.3% reported headaches, and 34.6% reported shortness of breath or rapid heartbeat. Many respondents also reported a decline in their work performance. The survey suggests that the Israeli population is still experiencing a high level of anxiety and depression, with 25.6% of respondents reporting anxiety, 22.6% reporting post-traumatic stress disorder, and 29% reporting depression. However, the survey also found that the level of depression and anxiety has decreased since the start of the war, and that the symptoms of post-traumatic stress disorder have also decreased. Professor Levi-Belz emphasized the need for accessible mental health treatment, saying, 'We must express this problem in words, tell about the complexity of functioning, deal with difficulties, and return to normal. Returning the kidnapped, for example, is a very important part of closing the trauma for many citizens and starting the healing of the psyche.'

**Survey: Israelis Feel Unprotected at Home and Abroad**
A recent survey by the Jewish Influence Center in collaboration with Geocartography Knowledge Group has revealed a complex picture of Israeli society's sentiments. The survey, conducted among 500 men and women from various social strata, shows that Israelis are concerned about their safety both within and outside the country. A third of the respondents expressed concern about their personal safety when traveling abroad, and 21% admitted that fear prevents them from traveling outside Israel. The majority of Israelis (73%) believe that the government's actions are insufficient to combat anti-Semitism and anti-Israeli sentiments worldwide. However, the survey also found areas where Israelis are more optimistic. The level of pessimism in society has decreased, with 61% of respondents expecting a deterioration in life in Israel in the coming months, down from 71% six months ago. This indicates a growing resilience and faith in the possibility of improving the situation. However, this optimism does not extend to personal safety, with only 29% of Israelis feeling secure, a figure unchanged since the previous survey in June 2024. The survey also highlighted the deep-seated divisions and tensions between Jews and Arabs in Israel, with only a third of respondents believing in the possibility of peaceful coexistence. Despite this, two-thirds of Israelis still believe that the country has the potential to become a united society, despite the ongoing discussions about national unity and cohesion. The survey also showed that ideological polarization is increasing, with 89% of Israelis agreeing that the war and its consequences have deepened ideological divisions, and nearly half of the respondents noting a shift to the right in the political and social discourse. However, there is a positive trend in relations with the diaspora, with more Israelis (43%) reporting a growing connection with Jews around the world, compared to 35% in June 2024. However, a significant portion of the population (38%) believes that relations are deteriorating. The survey also found that a majority of Israelis (56%) believe that Israel is successfully conducting its policy of deterrence since the start of the war on October 7. This reflects the collective determination of the country to protect its borders and maintain security in the face of growing threats. However, it is clear that the landscape of Israeli national security remains complex, and its ability to cope with challenges will require continued vigilance and strategic diplomacy. Despite the challenges facing Israel, the survey results also offer a reason for optimism. The resilience and unity of Israeli society are undeniable, even amidst ideological differences and external threats. There is a growing desire for change and growth, and a foundation for change is evident. The problems facing Israel are enormous, but they are not insurmountable. With continued efforts and a resolute commitment to dialogue, unity, and security both within and outside the country, the State of Israel can pave the way for a stronger and safer future for all its citizens. In this complex reality, the resilience of Israeli society offers hope that even the darkest times will give way to brighter days. The sun is already peeking through the clouds, and the society is feeling a sense of optimism that the future may be brighter than the recent past. This is an important moment to capture the positive momentum and precisely this is what we, as a society, must recognize. Robert Singerman, chairman of the Jewish Influence Center, member of the Board of Directors of the organization fighting against anti-Semitism, and former general director of the World Jewish Congress.

**Israelis Express Widespread Dissatisfaction with Netanyahu's Government**
A recent poll in Israel, conducted by the Israeli Public Broadcasting Corporation, has shown widespread discontent with the current government led by Benjamin Netanyahu, with 64% of respondents expressing dissatisfaction with the government's performance. The poll also showed that a majority of Israelis support the resignation of the Chief of Staff, Herzi Halevi, and the head of the 'Shin Bet' agency, Ronen Bar, due to harsh criticism of their performance, particularly after the October 7th attack. The Likud party, led by Netanyahu, has seen a decline in popularity, with 25 seats in the current poll, down from 26 in a previous poll. In contrast, former Prime Minister Naftali Bennett, who is running as an independent candidate, is expected to win 24 seats, making him the largest party. The poll also showed that Bennett is preferred by 38% of respondents to lead the government, compared to 35% who prefer Netanyahu. In other matchups, Netanyahu was preferred by 39% to Bennett, 29% to Gantz, and 40% to Ya'ir Lapid. 46% of respondents believe that Halevi and Bar should resign, while 28% oppose this, and 26% are unsure. 77% of respondents support the establishment of an independent committee to investigate the intelligence and security failures that led to the October 7th attack. 70% of respondents also support holding new elections as soon as the current war ends, considering the current political situation to be unsuitable for the government to continue. The poll also showed that 64% of Israelis believe that Netanyahu's government is 'not good', with 48% describing it as 'very bad', and 16% as 'not good'. In contrast, 30% believe that the government is 'good', with 9% considering it 'very good'. Regarding the impartiality of the investigations conducted by the Attorney General's office into Netanyahu's judicial files, 44% of respondents believe that the investigations are influenced by political considerations, while 33% believe they are professional. 23% are unsure.

**INSS Survey: Israelis' Confidence in IDF and Military Operations**
A recent survey conducted by the National Security Studies Center (INSS) found that the majority of Israelis (74.5% in the representative Israeli sample, 85% among the Jewish public, and 34% among the Arab public) have high confidence in the Israel Defense Forces (IDF). The survey also found that there is a slight increase in confidence in the Air Force (77% in the general sample, 87% among the Jewish public, and 37% among the Arab public) and the Intelligence Corps (61% in the general sample, 68% among the Jewish public, and 31% among the Arab public) compared to the previous survey in September 2024. However, there is a slight decrease in confidence in the Chief of Staff (46% in the representative Israeli sample, 52% among the Jewish public, and 22% among the Arab public) compared to the previous month. The survey also found that the majority of Israelis (65%) are confident that the IDF will win the war in Gaza, and 52% believe that the objectives of the war will be achieved to a large extent. Additionally, 68% of Israelis believe that the war will end with the release of all hostages, and 45% are concerned about the implications of the recent developments in Syria on Israel's national security. The survey also found that 59.5% of Israelis believe that the Israeli military operations in Syria have contributed significantly to the fall of the Assad regime. Furthermore, 45% of Israelis support the Israeli position that the IDF should maintain control over the disarmed area and Mount Druze until a new government is formed in Syria. The survey also found that 54% of Israelis oppose the establishment of a Palestinian state, and 30% support it under certain conditions. The survey was conducted by the INSS in December 2024 and had a sample size of 804 Jewish and 205 Arab respondents.

**Arab Israelis Show Increased Support for Two-State Solution and Inclusion in Israeli Government**
A recent survey by the University of Tel Aviv reveals a surprising trend: 57.8% of Arab Israelis, including Muslims, Druze, and Christians, believe that the ongoing war has contributed to a 'sense of shared destiny' with the Jewish community. This result, part of a study by the Moshe Dayan Center, marks a significant change from the past. In June 2024, 51.6% of respondents expressed a similar opinion, while in November 2023, just after the October 7 attacks, 69.8% believed that the war had damaged solidarity between the two communities. The war in Gaza seems to have sparked a new reflection on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict solution. Almost half of Arab Israelis (49.7%) now consider the two-state solution, based on the 1967 borders, the most realistic option, a significant increase from 17.2% in 2023. Meanwhile, pessimism decreases: only 27.1% believes that there are no political solutions in sight, compared to 55.6% last year. 'Before the October 2023 events, the majority of Arab Israelis believed that there was no practical political solution,' the report states. 'Today, the two-state solution is seen as the most realistic alternative.' Crime is the top concern, with 66.5% of respondents identifying it as the most urgent challenge, surpassing other priorities such as the Israeli-Palestinian conflict (10.9%) or poverty (4.9%). 'The growing violence, fueled by decades of government neglect and the proliferation of organized crime groups, has left many Arab communities in a state of insecurity,' the study's authors warn. 65.8% of respondents declare feeling insecure in their daily lives. Feeling Israeli: Arab Israeli identity is consolidating, with 33.9% indicating citizenship as the dominant component of their identity, followed by religious affiliation (29.2%) and Arab identity (26.9%). Only 9% considers Palestinian identity the core of their affiliation. Inclusion of Arab parties in the Israeli government enjoys broad support: 71.8% of respondents are in favor of this option, and almost half (47.8%) supports Arab party participation regardless of coalition orientation. The change is attributed to the experience of the Ra'am party, which supported the Bennett-Lapid coalition in 2021, setting a precedent for Arab Israeli politics. No to Hamas: Over half of Arab Israelis (53.4%) see a normalization agreement between Israel and Saudi Arabia as a positive opportunity, even without a preliminary resolution of the conflict with Palestinians. Only a minority (6.7%) supports Hamas continuing to govern Gaza, while other options – including Palestinian Authority involvement or multinational entities – gather significant consensus. 'Arab Israelis are sending a clear message to authorities and the Jewish majority,' says Arik Rudnitzky, research director. 'They are ready to collaborate to rebuild Israeli society after this war.'

**More than Half of Israelis Concerned about 'Democracy' in the Knesset**
A recent survey by the 'Israeli Democracy Institute' found that 20% of Israelis believe the situation in the country is good, while more than half are concerned that there will be no 'democracy'. According to the 'Walla' website, there was a significant increase in the percentage of those who describe the general situation in 'Israel' as bad or very bad, with around 48% saying they feel that way. On the other hand, there was an increase in the percentage of those who describe the situation in 'Israel' as good or very good, with 19% and 32% respectively. The Israeli army is the most trusted institution, with a 77% trust rate in the sample in October 2024. The Prime Minister comes second with a 38% trust rate. The police trust rate increased after the October 7, 2023 events, but decreased significantly last year from 55% to 37%. The Supreme Court trust rate remained largely unchanged. Only about a quarter of the Israeli public trusts the government, and 16% trust the Knesset. A majority of the Jewish public (around 56%) is optimistic about Israel's future, while the Arab public has the opposite view, with around 59% being pessimistic. In a similar division, around 77% of the Arab public believes that the future of democracy is at risk, while the percentage in the Jewish public is 54%. Between May and October, there was a decrease in the percentage of those who believe that strengthening the military power will ensure a safer future for 'Israel' on the short term, from 40% to 30%, while there was an increase in the percentage of those who believe that a political settlement will ensure their safety more, from 19% to 28%.
